prompt.question: Is a woman's only purpose to make babies and be ruled by her husband?
prompt.response:
The story of Adam and Eve is DEEPLY symbolic. This isn't the standard take, but it's one I'm comfortable giving as an answer to a very good question. 

Take Eve as symbolic of the impulse to try new things, explore, and learn. She dives into the world of chaos, and brings down the world of paradise with her. Take Adam as the one who follows the rules. When things get a bit out of control, he's the one who establishes order and control again. Now, consider that you have an "Adam" and an "Eve" inside of you. If Adam were in control, nothing would ever change and no growth would ever occur. If Eve were in control, we'd descend into chaos with no hope of ever climbing back out. Eve is the one who brings about new things, and those new things almost always involve struggle. "I will greatly multiply thy sorrow and thy conception". And when that happens, we instinctively try to make sense of the new world we find ourselves in. "thy desire shall be to thy husband, and he shall rule over thee." 

Rather than reading this as a reinforcement of gender roles, take it as a window into your own psyche.

prompt.referenceText: And I saw the Lord; and he stood before my face, and he talked with me, even as a man talketh one with another, face to face; and he said unto me: Look, and I will show unto thee the world for the space of many generations.
prompt.question: Why does the Lord show himself in different forms?
prompt.response: The scriptures are pretty clear that when anyone receives the privilege of seeing God, it happens with "spiritual eyes" rather than "natural ones". I can't say exactly how that changes the rules of perception, but I'm sure that it does. My guess is that God shows us what we need to understand.

prompt.referenceText:
58 And again Enoch wept and cried unto the Lord, saying: When shall the earth rest?
61 And the day shall come that the earth shall rest, but before that day the heavens shall be darkened, and a veil of darkness shall cover the earth; and the heavens shall shake, and also the earth; and great tribulations shall be among the children of men, but my people will I preserve
prompt.question: When does rest come?
prompt.response: A lot of times we want rest to come immediately. But God was teaching Enoch that that's not actually the way things work. The dark times still need to be passed through. We can't just skip over them. But, the promise to the righteous is the God is with us even during the dark times, and that hope and faith will get us through to the peaceful rest.

16 And from that time forth there were wars and bloodshed among them; but the Lord came and dwelt with his people, and they dwelt in righteousness.
17 The fear of the Lord was upon all nations, so great was the glory of the Lord, which was upon his people. And the Lord blessed the land, and they were blessed upon the mountains, and upon the high places, and did flourish.
prompt.question: If the people "dwelt in righteousness" they why was the Lord feared instead of loved?
prompt.response: In this verse specifically, the ones that feared God were the OTHER nations, not Enoch's rightous city. There are plenty of places in the scriptures though where "fear" means "respect". We'll read a lot of places where we're commanded to "fear the Lord", and these are really instructions to respect God and the commandments we receive.

prompt.referenceText: And it came to pass that Enoch continued his speech, saying: Behold, our father Adam taught these things, and many have believed and become the sons of God, and many have believed not, and have perished in their sins, and are looking forth with fear, in torment, for the fiery indignation of the wrath of God to be poured out upon them.
prompt.question: Why will the sinners perish/not be forgiven?
prompt.response: Enoch is talking about the atonement, and that Christ will forgive everyone who comes and sincerely repents. All paths to forgivness lead through Christ, and if people will not come to him, they remain spiritually stuck where they are until they realize that there is peace available to them.

3 And it came to pass that I turned and went up on the mount; and as I stood upon the mount, I beheld the heavens open, and I was clothed upon with glory;
4 And I saw the Lord; and he stood before my face, and he talked with me, even as a man talketh one with another, face to face; and he said unto me: Look, and I will show unto thee the world for the space of many generations.
prompt.question: What does it mean to be "clothed up with glory"?
prompt.response:
Being "clothed with glory" is mentioned a lot in the scriptures, especially when someone is being prepared to meet God. Other times it's described as being surrounded by fire, which I think is a metaphor for brightness, energy, and power beyond our usual ability to describe. In the temple, we wear special white robes over our clothes that represent being clothed with glory. 

Glory is how we'll be ressurrected, and it's a restoration of all the good things we've tried to be and do in our life. Being clothed with glory is getting a taste of what the celestial kingdom will be like, so that you can have a celestial experience here.

prompt.referenceText: 18 And the Lord called his people Zion, because they were of one heart and one mind, and dwelt in righteousness; and there was no poor among them.
prompt.question: How is Zion different from the rest of the world?
prompt.response: Zion is different becuase instead of fighting with each other, with everyone competing to be the best, they work together, and look after one another. Instead of arguing to convince someone that they're right, people in Zion listen to each other and try to understand each other. They share easily, and always work to include people in righteousness.

prompt.question: How is the flood like baptism?
prompt.response: The earth was covered with water, just like we are when we're baptised. Also, the world was sinful, just like us when we're baptised. God established his covenant with Noah, just like he does with us. And when we keep that covenant, we help save our families and all the other good things in our lives.

prompt.referenceText: And of every living thing of all flesh, two of every sort shalt thou bring into the ark, to keep them alive with thee; they shall be male and female
prompt.question: Why did God have Noah save the animals, rather than just save them Himself? Is there anything we can learn from that?
prompt.response: One thing I learn from that is that even when it feels like my whole world is going wrong, I have a responsibility to find and protect the good things that God has given me. And even when everything feels bad, that's still a LOT of things. Enough to fill an enormous ark.
